<review# 1,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/26/2014,9/18/2014,20,109,4,5,4>While it may seem a bit dark on first impression, this is an excellent place to enjoy some spectacular offerings and stellar service.Came here yesterday with a lady friend trying to round out my card for the "Richmond Burger Week" and I was surprised they had so many offerings. Turned out that I was not only there during Burger Week but also on their $5 burger night! It's Burger-ception! It was a tough choice given all the great options on the list, though in the end I opted for The Godfather, a delicious burger served on a focaccia bun with marinara and fresh mozzarella on top. My friend ordered a sausage/pepper pasta. She got a caesar salad included in the price of her pasta (which tasted fresh), and the warm bread they brought to our table was great too. Both of our entrees were spectacular, and the portions were extremely generous as well. Once I polished off my meal, I helped her work on her pasta and we still didn't even manage to down half of it. Now those are portion sizes that make you want to say " 'Murica"!Service was excellent and very attentive, with refills coming in fast and furious whenever they were needed. As a server/bartender myself, I have to applaud them on their attention to this critical detail. Whether you're a glass-half-full or glass-half-empty kind of person, no one likes an empty glass!The bill at the end was more than reasonable given our fullness, though we did avoid alcohol so I can't comment on that aspect. All in all, this place was quite a find and I'd definitely return to try some of their other unique offerings!Overall: 4.5 stars-------------Pros:- Tons of menu options.- Food was excellent.- Wednesday Burger Night makes it all so much more satisfying/cheap.- Service was quite good, though admittedly we did come slightly earlier than the dinner rush.Cons:- Inside is quite dark, though if you like that intimate dinner feeling this won't trouble you much.- Volume wasn't too bad when we went, though I can see it being a problem during their peak business hours.

It will satisfy any chocolate craving that you may have, and then some. When I say the slices of cake are huge, I mean it! These are no normal cake size slices, so be prepared to share, or take some home with you.The service here is great! Let me say that Shyndigz is so worth the wait! I also love that they added another day to their hours of operation. <review# 4,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/5/2014,9/15/2014,22,146,3,5,6>We came by on Cinco de Mayo because, well, tacos. All of our fave Mexican spots were overflowing with would-be diners, so we decided to try some place off the beaten path. It was a really great find. In the middle of an aging office park is a gem of a taco spot with an expansive menu. It is bright and modern and has those cute little globe lights strung across the ceiling. All of their tacos were $1 on this festive day, so we were super happy about that. Normally they run ~$3/taco with discounts if you order 3 (you will want at least 3!), and they have lots of great daily specials that include $2 tacos and such.We tried the crunchy fish, carnitas, and steak tacos. Steak tacos are usually my fave, but here they were not. They skimped on the meat quality here and cut it into the tiniest cubes I've ever seen. The crunchy fish and carnitas tacos were awesome! The tacos were smaller than expected, but well-priced. People who generally eat 3 tacos might actually eat 4 here. We also ordered the chips and dip trio which came with queso, salsa, and their special blended guacomole (sour cream, garlic, avocado). Each dip was outstanding, and very different from any I've tasted at other places. The chips were light and crispy, almost wafer thin. Sooo good! Can't wait to go back!Service deserves a mention here. I was a little disappointed to see that this was an order-at-the-counter type place, but still we experienced great customer service. They do have runners bring your food to you at your chosen table, and they even brought our chips and dip out to us asap so we could munch while waiting for tacos (without asking). I asked for sour cream and it was delivered with a smile. So many carry-out places have a tip jar, but employees don't do anything to earn it. That is NOT the case here.

<review# 13,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/9/2014,2/18/2014,246,313,3,11,8>Great museum. It was very educational and had some nice exhibits.  The audio tour is the way to go. It lasts about 90 mins and a former holocaust survivor talks you through the museum.There is a flow to the museum which demonstrates the whole cycle of events.  You start off with the persecution of Jews and then onto the round up and forced placement into ghettos.  From there you experience the travel to death camps, life at death camps and the gas chambers. Then life after the camps for the survivors and the subsequent war trials for the people carrying out the atrocities. Very hands on museum and they do a good job of making you feel like you are there. There is even one part where you have to crawl on your hands and knees through a tunnel escaping from the ghetto. There is an alternative route for those who are not physically able or those not wanting to crawl.Museum is totally free, just takes donations. Not for young children. I would recommend teenagers and up due to the graphic nature of some content. It is a good way to spend a couple of hours.

The other side of the restaurant contains several booths for smaller groups. Yes, it's not SF/NY-Chinatown-satisfying, but good enough for Richmond. In my opinion, a better choice when compared to Full Kee. Shu Mai: the prototypical favorite of pork dumplings garnished with a bit of crab roe2. Fried taro: dumpling look-alikes containing delicious mashed taro with a meat center and a crumbly fried batter as its outer shell.3. Har gow: chewy shrimp dumplings, feel free to dip in soy sauce4. Lo mai gai: MUST get. Essentially glutinous sticky rice with some meat and mushrooms wrapped in a lotus leaf (leaves are not meant to be eaten...).5. Turnip cake: fried daikon radish + shrimp in rectangular/square shapes. Sprinkle with some soy sauce for the best taste.6. Shrimp noodle rolls: wide flat rice noodles wrapped around shrimp and dressed with soy sauce. Simple but a childhood favorite. *must order from a menu, not on carts7. Egg custard: an sweet egg mixture in a well-done pastry cup. Overall, Queen's exceeded my expectations quite a bit. $13/person incl. tip for a group of 10 and fairly full bellies. Certainly worth a quick drive over to check out the dim sum.
<review# 15,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/7/2013,2/16/2014,61,189,2,9,4>Bahn Mi.I'm not sure I need to say more but I will.Bahn Mi!If you have not eaten these amazing Vietnamese sandwiches, you are missing a true pleasure in life.   I read a little on the Internet (so it must be true!) and learned that bahn mi is actually just the light and crispy baguette on which these sandwiches are made; it's the rest of the name that makes the magic.  My favorite from Catina so far is the #11 bahn mi heo nuong, which is made with thinly sliced Vietnamese grilled pork.  I've also had the #10 bahn mi ga nuong (grilled chicken) and #1 bahn mi thit nguoi (cold cuts).  All were delicious! I'm not sure I want to tell you all the typical ingredients, just so you'll try them "as is" and judge for yourself.  There's nothing on any of these that will hurt you (just meats, vegetables, and condiments), but some of you might not think of these flavors on a traditional American sandwich.  It's the bahn mi ingredients that make them so good, in my opinion.  For you Subway fans out there, this is nothing like Subway where you pick and choose the ingredients as they build it before your eyes.  To get the best sandwich I'd recommend you simply step up, request the sandwich by number, pay your $3.50, and patiently wait a few minutes for your your paper-wrapped, rubber band-sealed grinder of goodness.  Your courageousness will pay off!
<review# 16,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/5/2013,2/15/2014,84,184,2,8,6>Easily one of my favorite restaurants in Richmond!  Make a reservation in advance if you want to guarantee yourself a table.  This place is always crowded for one main reason - the food is AMAZING!  Plenty of options for meat eaters, vegetarians, and seafood lovers so there is something for everyone.  They serve "mezze" dishes (shared plates) so everyone can have a bite but don't over-order because portions are VERY generous plus they start you off with a bread basket that you can dip in Greek olive oil.Favorite dishes include: Lamb Frites (I adore this dish and leftovers make for a great breakfast hash), Grilled Octopus (an unexpected favorite dish, tastes like a combo of lobster and calamari), Saganaki (salted, flaming cheese - so addicting), Cypriot Salad (unique salad with grapes, pistachios, and mint - very refreshing), and Moussaka (have tried both meat and vegetarian - kinda like a Greek lasagna that has a touch of sweetness from cinnamon = true comfort food).  The Zucchini fritters, Stella's Kalamari (sauteed with tomatoes), and the Chicken Souvlaki are also good choices.  Don't forget to ask about specials because there are lots of choices.  We loved our special mezze of seared scallops with sauteed chicken livers.They also do happy hour from 4pm-6pm, Monday-Friday and serve select small plates and drink special (cocktails are unexpectedly good and there's a nice wine list).  If you arrive during peak hours, you might be lucky to grab a spot at the bar or at the communal table.  Highly recommend Stella's, it will soon become one of your favorites.  And ask Sarah for your server, she rocks!

<review# 61,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/3/2014,4/21/2014,14,38,1,9,7>I went here tonight on a whim after hearing good things, and I was in the area.First off - the location.  When you drive up, the place looks abandoned, but it's because it's the only thing bringing in business in the entire shopping center (whatever the big store is next door was already closed, or near about empty, at 7 PM), but the section of the building for Mission BBQ looks warm and welcoming.And, come on, there's an army truck outside.  That's kinda cool.The place, despite outside appearances, was hopping.  I probably had to wait about 10 minutes to place my order.  The layout is similar to how Qdoba or Chipotle works - the line forms on one side of the large, open room, you place your order with a cashier and pay up front, wait for your name to be called and grab your tray, and sit down wherever you please.  One of the workers brought people standing in line a sample of the jalapeño and cheese sausage, and it almost made me change my mind on the pork/brisket sampler.But I stood firm.  I got the pork and brisket sampler, with a side of fries (the XL Combo) and a drink.  While waiting for my food, I saw several people with what appeared to be the most delicious mac and cheese I've ever seen, and I almost asked to change my side option.  But that was a very short time I had to wait.  My food was ready before I had a chance to even put a lid on my cup.  I was almost worried because I thought it might be a bit like fast food barbecue.The meal itself came with a piece of cornbread, and the worker asked if it was my first time here.  He told me about how the meats were cooked, and the sauces that were on the table.  It was welcoming, but it felt a little long-winded - I already ordered the meat, I kinda didn't care how many hours they were in the smoker at this point, I just wanted to put my fork in it.The first thing I bit into was one of the french fries.  They were crispy with a good amount of seasoning on them (but not too much).  However, after digging into the meat, I didn't even want them anymore because the meat and cornbread was so delicious.The pork barbecue was something of a mix between a NC style and a KC/Tennessee style - it was thick and hearty, but had a lightness to it at the same time.  It was similar to Buz & Neds, but a little less heavy and rich.  It paired really well with the honey hot sauce.The brisket, however, was probably one of the best I've ever had.  The cashier that took my order asked if I wanted it "lean" or "wet," and I got it wet.  I think I can guess what the difference might be, but I'm not positive.  I stuck my fork in it and it just fell apart.  I didn't even need a knife.  The flavors were, similar to the pork, strong but light.  You can taste the smoke in every bite, and the crispy ends made it all the more delicious.  I tried several sauces on it, but, honestly, it didn't need them.The cornbread is what I envision the perfect cornbread to be.  It was somewhat dense, but didn't feel too heavy or buttery when you took a bite, and you get a nice note of sweetness from the corn.  It was a good way to cool down the spicier sauces (which, by the way, weren't overly spicy at all).The only thing I would say was bad about the experience was the method of placing your order.  The cashier and pickup area has too many people crammed in a small space - people placing orders, picking up their meal, getting their drinks, and all their condiments.  Thankfully, that area was where people spent the least amount of time because the food came up so quickly, and I can imagine that, on a slower night, it would be fine.All in all, after tonight's meal, I have a new top favorite barbecue restaurant in Richmond, and I would advise anyone to go here and check it out.

<review# 66,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/26/2014,4/16/2014,80,45,5,10,7>Short of a flight over the Atlantic, La Grotta is a phenomenal, authentic dining experience fit for a king and is delivered by a richly-seasoned, Italian-trained chef.Richmond residents benefit greatly from the fortune of owner-Chef Antonio Capece's immigration from Italy in 1981 and his move from the busy-streets of Washington DC to the family-friendly RVA. From the decor, to the service, to the food - you can tell that Tony is bringing you every bit of his Northern Italy heritage that he can!Our party elected to try the Four Course meal, each of us selecting our own combination of delicious choices from Pasta, Salad, Entree, and Dessert. I would certainly suggest taking the recommendation of the Chef when possible, unless your heart is set on a certain cuisine. My meal consisted of a sampling of Gnocchi al Filetto di Pomodoro, Agnolotti alla Panna, Ravioli di Aragosta, Torretta, Gamberoni e Cape Sante Con Polenta Fra Diavolo, and Tiramisu."Say what?!", You ask? Yes, a majority of the items on this menu are completely in Italian adding a very comical flare to any dining experience with non-Italian speaking guests. Ours, certainly, was nothing short of a 1960s comedy routine. Don't fret though, each of them has a very wonderful description. Like most ethnic places, French, Italian, etc. - my recommendation is to order based on the description. "I'll have the Shrimp and Scallops with Polenta" worked just fine.The journey through Northern Italy began with a sampling of freshly made pastas and sauces elevated by nuanced flavor. The first bite hit my palate with a bright, fresh, acidic Filetto di Pomodoro sauce smothering small pillows of potato pasta. The Gnocchi was perfectly chewy and flavorful, enough to sop up the delicious sliced (filetto) plum tomato (pomodoro)  sauce - traditionally from Northern Italy - and compliment the sharp notes of fresh herbs and strong garlic aromas. Next, the spinach and ricotta ravioli was a wonderfully light and airy contrast to the dense tomato gravy. Draped in a surprisingly light cream sauce, each of these elements managed to share the stage with the spinach within. Finally, the star of the show, a Lobster-stuffed ravioli. Complete with a seafood bisque as the sauce, it was buttery, rich, and perfectly cooked. I would like to say that I am joking, but a straw was used to finish off the bisque by one member of our group (who should thank me for anonymity). The sauce alone could serve as an outstanding appetizer.Meal over? No. That was the first course.My salad course was equally delightful. A colorful, towering stack of roasted red pepper, marinated eggplant, and house mozzarella covered in basil, oregano, oil, and an immensely rich aged balsamic vinegar. Each ingredient was a star on its own but the combination filled my mouth with a cacophony of flavorful notes.To my delight, the "sautéed jumbo shrimp and sea scallops with crushed red pepper and saffron in a tomato cognac sauce over polenta" was a much spicier rendition of the amazing tomato sauce adorning my gnocchi. Sampling the red pepper sauce with a bite of fresh bread, this is no medium-spice dish. The flavorful cognac sauce added a wonderful bite and heat to elevate it one notch higher than the cuisine served before it. While my scallops were cooked to perfection, the only flaw in my entire meal was slightly overcooked shrimp (full tail-on, which also bothers me, instead of trimmed).Finally, the crème de la crème of Tiramisu. Rich chocolate, deep dark aromas of expresso, sweet and spongy ladyfingers soaking up all the flavors, served over a champagne-laced pudding worthy of being served on its own, accompanied by chocolate. Seriously. The best dessert in Richmond? Possibly.Go to La Grotta. It is absolutely worth every penny. Enjoy a taste of Northern Italy.

Oh yeah - they also have Tiger beer from Singapore, one of my favorites - perfect with the spring rolls!For dinner, I went with the traditional Pho - when in Rome - the number 11.  It had beef broth, rice noodles, eye of round, brisket and meatballs.  The bowl is huge!  So much food for $8.50!!  The meatballs were very good; the broth not salty, just right; and the extras - bean sprouts, cilantro and jalepenos all added at will, made this Pho and instant favorite.  My wife had the #37 - wok stir fry - with chicken, broccoli and bok choy.  I have to say, I ate alot of hers too.  Very flavorful and fresh ingredients.  Even with the added apps (3) and a couple of beers the bill was very reasonable for such a great dinner - about $45.  I think you could eat a great meal here for less than $12 per person.  If I could change one thing about the experience I would have wished for the waitress to know a little more about the Vietnamese food so she could have explained the menu to us.  Even with that, she was a great waitress and we enjoyed our evening.I will definitely be back.J

<review# 75,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/14/2012,6/25/2012,55,198,,4,3>This is my favorite park in all of Richmond (though Forest Hill Park is a close second).  This place just screams Richmond to me and floods me with nostalgia anytime I visit.  There are two lakes to walk around (one with a lighted fountain, paddle boats and concession stand), ducks to feed and a track to walk or run!  It's set in a beautiful neighborhood and, my favorite feature, it's accessible at night for a romantic midnight stroll (or maybe some necking and petting in your car).  Don't forget about the Carillon (the big bell tower) and amphitheater at Dogwood Dell as well as the tennis courts across the streets - some people refer to these as separate sites.  And of course there's nearby Maymont Park for those who want to walk through peaceful gardens or see animals.  This entire complex has something for everyone!

<review# 94,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/7/2014,5/18/2014,83,61,6,12,8>Richmond is so lucky to have a place like this in the heart of the city. The museum not only has a great set of collections that are on year-round exhibit, but it draws special exhibits of international fame, including ancient Egyptian, Chihuly, and artistic mega-stars like Monet and Picasso. At times, VMFA is the only east coast museum to host these exhibits, making it a destination for someone who appreciates art--from the casual "oooh, pretty!" to the super serious, "You can see the influence of the times--look at how he uses a dog as a metaphor!"With free admission to year-round exhibits (but please feel free to donate!) and reasonably priced admission (and membership!) to special exhibits, the VMFA is a great way to spend an afternoon without shelling out too much money.Having gone through a major renovation a few years ago, the bright, easily navigated museum is large, walkable, and beautiful. Whether you're interested in modern art or ancient Roman coinage, you'll find something to love!

Everybody else is playing for second place after you try these. They also serve them with a variety of sauces. The garlic aioli is something that has to be experienced. If you're a garlic lover, you're going to have a good time.In closing I'm not sure what else there is to say.  This place serves gourmet burgers at a gourmet price. Is it worth it? Time for you to be the judge.

<review# 107,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/27/2014,7/24/2014,33,52,7,7,7>When you leave the place you were born to find your fortune elsewhere, then return 30-some years later, the dividing line between "old" and "new" is quite obvious. Westbury Pharmacy was here when we moved into the neighborhood in 1970. It's not only still here today but thrives as an industrial-strength pharmacy (seriously, there are like 10 or 12 pharmacists and an army of cashiers behind a fortress of cash registers) but also serves as a social spot for mostly senior citizens. There are gifts and chotzkes, a full candy store with all the stuff your Grandmother had, and a large, bustling cafe serving excellent, dependable food at very very reasonable prices.  A full breakfast is $5. Inside the pharmacy is a good size Kosher market with everything from produce to matzoh. And The Mixing Bowl, an unabashedly Southern bakery, fills space that once was part of the Kosher market (again, I've been gone a long time). Visit the bakery for decadent, over the top goodies to take home after your visit. In addition to everything you would usually find in a pharmacy, Westbury has an entire wing devoted to all things medical for your patients at home, from oxygen bottles to an array of medical reclining loungers, again, with a large, friendly and helpful staff to help you find anything you might need. This is "old" Richmond at its best and a welcome place to sit and relax over a quick sandwich while you wait for your prescription to be filled.

<review# 118,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/26/2013,10/16/2013,46,109,3,3,3>Recently, I agreed with another reviewer that said if you are truly to judge a sushi place, stick with the basics and see if they distinguish themselves.  The special rolls, while good for pictures, don't always make a difference unless you are trying to impress a date with how much money you can spend.  So with that in mind, I must say that Hanami does a terrific job with the basic sushi derivatives as well as their higher priced "artistic" creations.  After I watched "Jiro Dreams Of Sushi" (just view the trailer to see how seriously sushi is taken in Japan) and really got an appreciation for this craft and it's centuries-old tradition, I really tried to get inside the head, mind, and stomach of who makes this stuff.  What are they most proud of? What sets them apart from the other restaurants that serve this?  If you ask a waiter or waitress, they'll tell you.  They will also tell you what is fresh, what is best suited to your palate and what, on that day, you may want to avoid.  For them, there is no honor in pushing the slow-moving stuff.  Hanami came closest so far in Richmond to what I experienced in Japan, even at a "chain" sushi restaurant in the Shibuya section of town, it's really like a familial atmosphere, where fish is eaten one piece at a time, and when a cooler came in with fresh fish, there was no doubt that you needed to order another round of tuna rolls, right then and there.  I believe that to be true about most of the decent places I have eaten sushi, the proof is in the ingredients and the care the creators take.  In the food at Hanami, you taste the care and feel satisfied that this chef and his understudies understand what is necessary to make his food stand above the rest.To the other things we got, appetizers like the shrimp shumai and tempura were also delicious, as well as the special Kani Miso soup with crab.  So, foodies dragging kids and the less adventurous shouldn't fear.  But, for those looking for the real deal, and can't get to Ginza Station in Tokyo and spend upwards of 500 dollars for a seat in his train station restaurant, happily, there is Hanami.  Enjoy!

A leg and thigh sat on top of a large beige waffle with green beans and syrup to the side. No frills, but you would be deceived to think it wasn't deep below the surface.The chicken tasted like meat, not a secret recipe. I could have as easily come from Mama's kitchen as Tarrant's. They chose to use a plain waffle, fluffy like a biscuit (although, I would have liked a crisper waffle). They made a dish for our tastebuds instead of our eyes. It's a great representation of a modern taqueria. There were discounted drink specials for happy hour, but no food specials. I had a Jamaica (hibiscus flavor) agua fresca drink with vodka. It was very unique, delicious, and super cheap for happy hour. My friend had the margarita on the rocks, she said it was good. She ordered chips with salsa, and the salsa that was included was a very spicy pico de gallo which I prefer on tacos, not chips. I had to ask for salsa verde, and that was excellent, not to mention unlimited.The tacos were the best ones I've had in a while. I ordered the taco plate (2 tacos and 2 sides) and got one al pastor and one carne asada. The meat was so tender and super flavorful, and the corn tortillas were perfect. I think they left out the pineapple that should have been on my taco al pastor, but no big deal. The frijoles charros (beans with bacon) were so flavorful and a great choice. My friend ordered the tostadas and those looked delicious as well. Authenticity abounds here. The only reason I didn't give them that extra star is because the portions are small. I didn't leave feeling full. And I brought my husband home a taco plate as well, and he was underwhelmed because of how little food there was. The taco plate is a good lunch size, but if you're really hungry 2 tacos is not enough. Next time, we will definitely order more. And there will absolutely be a next time.

<review# 158,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/9/2014,9/1/2014,80,45,3,6,3>Heritage is a beautiful and sophisticated eatery serving up deep-flavors originating from in-and-around the Greater Richmond area. These flavors are skillfully elevated by artistically-talented Chef Joe Sparatta, in both execution and presentation,  and complimented by the delicious mixology created by Mattias Hägglund.Apart from a view of the patrons at Home Team Grill during our dining experience, the meal, drinks, and service at Heritage were nothing short of warm, inviting, and comforting while still maintaining a level of formality for a Friday evening dinner date.After a short wait we were greeted by a wonderfully knowledgeable server who was able to articulate the local businesses and farms being featured on the menu, as well as, the Chef's specials for the evening.The menu is arranged into Small Plates, Medium Plates, and Large Plates. We elected to start off our meal with the pimento croquettes (small) and the local asparagus (medium).The croquettes came out piping hot, radiant golden brown, and perfectly crispy. The flavors of the sharp pimento cheese balanced well with the slight saltiness and density of the thin breading. The texture of the perhaps-overly-melted cheese was slightly grainy for my taste, but that is an overstated nuance to an overall great bite. Served alongside was an aromatic smoked tomato aioli that only made the second bite even better adding a note of acidity and another level of flavor.As for the local asparagus, this is where the artwork at Heritage began. A beautifully plated dish, the asparagus was served perfectly charred with a bit of crispness. The spears were accompanied by two medallions of purple potato, morsels of fatty and salty house bacon, shavings of parmesan, and a delicately poached egg with a whimsical drizzle of aioli / oil surrounding. The presentation, complexity, and depth were immaculate for a dish entitled "local asparagus".Our entrees were the roasted half chicken served over rich-and-creamy cheddar grits from Byrd Mill and the Chef's special - Waygu Beef and Broccoli. The chicken, competing with a similar dish from The Daily Kitchen and Bar eaten a night earlier, showcased its superiority with a golden, crispy, fatty, salty skin encasing juicy, moist white meat representative of the level of execution in the kitchen. Served on rectangular slate dish, perfectly medium rare thin slices of the Wagyu beef met with a deliciously rich, sweet and spicy sauce and was served over light and crisp bunches of local victory farms broccoli. The warmth and depth of flavor of this simple dish was an immaculate feature of the evening.Finally, another piece of artwork from the Chef hidden behind a simple name: the chocolate candy bar. A splay of meringue zigzagged across the plate, slightly burnt adding a scrumptious campfire/marshmallow essence to the dish. Centered-atop, a thin bar of creamy chocolate hazelnut fudge with droppings of candied corn pops nestled up against a scoop of Nutella ice cream. The richness, the sugar, the hot and the cold, the textures all created one of the best desserts we've eaten in 2014.Heritage, Joe, Mattias, and crew - You all have done something special and we can not wait to return to try the rest of the menu!

The collection of pieces that are original to the house is just mind blowing, from the stained glass, to the Tiffany & Co pieces, to the diningware, and my favorite the books in the library.  Gosh, I would love to have a room like that library with the built in half wall bookshelves. Along the tour you not only get to see these remarkable treasures, but our guide helped to paint a good picture of what life was like during that time.  Separate drawing rooms, even separate bedrooms at some points, the parties and the history of the grounds.  Maymont is somewhere that I would take any history buff to see when they were visiting Richmond.

<review# 179,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/26/2013,1/13/2014,89,171,9,14,9>I decided that for my 100th review I wanted to review somewhere that serves up one of my favorite foods.  As I've already eaten at half a dozen pho places and almost as many taquerias, I decided that it was time to eat at a real authentic Philly style cheesesteak shop.The problem with this is that RVA seems to be almost completely devoid of anything that falls into this category.  Sure, there are Italian and sub shops that have Steak and Cheese, but these are all put on hard deli rolls with lettuce, tomato, and mayo.  I was looking for a classic Philly Cheesesteak.--Food: Str8 Out of Philly is a no frills, honest to goodness Philly Cheesesteak shop.  I ordered a classic style Cheesesteak with Provolone (although you can opt for Cheez Whiz), Mushrooms, and Banana Peppers.  The bread is in the form of a fresh tasting Amoroso roll, which if you've ever had a legit Philly Cheesesteak, you know this is the only way to go.  It's soft and flavorful and just delicious.  The steak itself is what you'd expect; thinly sliced steak which is then diced and melted with provolone.  Str8 Out of Philly captures all of the flavor that I associate with a real deal cheesesteak with the delicious roll, properly prepared steak, and overall Philly Cheesesteak feel.I also had fries with the lunch combo I ordered, served in the crinkle cut variety.  They were good, but I wouldn't return for the fries.  BUT THAT CHEESESTEAK.  I used to eat at a few Philly Cheesesteak places in Upstate NY, and Str8 Out of Philly is on par, if not better.--Cost: Very fair.  My combo was about $11, and the "Half" cheesesteak was no less than 10 inches long, maybe more.  I was starving when I came here and it was a chore to finish, but was so good I couldn't resist.  Best $11 I've spent in a while.--Service: Alright, so I'm not going to sugar coat this.  The service is mediocre at best.  My order of a cheesesteak and fries took about 25 minutes, and my order was the first one of all the people there (which was only two other people).  The employees aren't rude, but didn't go out of their way to be overly pleasant either.  Although the cook did ask me how things were.--Atmosphere: Again, no sugar coating, I've been to nicer places.  I think that Str8 Out of Philly aims to be more of a pickup place as there are 3 tables with 2 chairs each in a small dining area.  The area is partially unfinished with loose cords and taped walls.  I didn't notice anything overly dirty as a couple reviews mentioned, but I've certainly seen nicer interiors.  BUT THAT CHEESESTEAK.--Overall: Simply put, if you're looking for a real Philly Cheesesteak and none of that lettuce, tomato, and mayo nonsense, do yourself a favor and come here.  The wait is a little long so if you can, order in advance, but the resulting cheesesteak speaks for itself.If you're wondering why I give it a 5 despite the service and interior, the answer is clear.  THAT CHEESESTEAK.

It is in a little strip mall off of Broad St. near Gaskins Rd. The soup, though, was a gigantic portion of fresh veggies and tofu with all of the traditional toppings (and if you are like me, you are heavy on the basil--they give you plenty of everything here). I did scarf almost my entire bowl of soup down while still attempting to maintain the effect of not being a starving person that has no manners to boot. I have been there numerous times after that, and each time it has been just as great. My husband loves it too, although he is a fan of the rice noodle bowls (which are also great... as is everything that we have tried). The dumplings are the best thing that I have had actually--something that they put in that sauce is so delicious that I could put it on almost everything that I ever eat (if I had the chance to do that--I'm sure they wouldn't like me taking their stock just so that my food at home would be tastier). They are suffering a bit from growing pains, and the last time that I went there they were so busy that they were a bit more scattered in service, but they made up for that by making sure that everything was completely right. We left just as happy, and we're both excited to see this restaurant do well. The owner is awesome and talks to everyone at some point while you are there to make sure that you are enjoying everything. Really, overall it is a great business to contribute to, and you will be happy (and overstuffed) when leaving.

<review# 247,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/25/2014,6/4/2014,89,171,9,14,12>I haven't had the honors to visit Sugar Shack's original location yet, so when this location opened literally a 4 minute walk from where I work, of course I'm going to check it out.--Donuts: The donuts here as others have mentioned are the fluffy variety as opposed to the dense cake style donut.  In my opinion, every good donut is a fluffy one, so this fits my preferences perfectly.I went in the morning and was brought to a full spread of flavors.  The young lady at the counter went through the entire case for myself and a couple other patrons, which was well appreciated because there are literally over 20 flavors.  There are glazed, frosted, powdered, and plain donuts with all sorts of frosting, flavors, and topping combinations. The variety was actually quite impressive for only having this location open for less than a week.With my fiancee and I in mind, I purchased 2 Strawberry Glazed, 2 Cinnamon Sugar, 1 Oreo (Vanilla frosted with Oreo pieces), and 1 Chocolate Frosted.  They have some unique flavors like strawberry coconut, maple bacon, and different candy toppings.The Strawberry Glazed was an immediate favorite and differs than every other strawberry donut I've had in the past.  As opposed to being a strawberry / vanilla frosting like Dunkin Donuts, Sugar Shack's variety is more of, as it sounds, a glaze.  There are also pieces of actual strawberry in it, which is something I can always appreciate.  The Cinnamon Sugar donut was also superb and true to the variety everyone knows and loves.Flavors aside, the quality of the donut is fantastic.  Plenty of donut shops fall into the category of their donuts innately falling flat, drying out, or not being fluffy.  Sugar Shack's donuts are exactly what any fluffy donut lover desires; large fluffy donuts that aren't greasy or dense yet provide that delightfully fried soft doughy consistency and flavor.  They're filling but not heavy and large but not overwhelming.  They're damn good.As the name indicates, they also have an extensive coffee and beverage selection, but I passed as I'm not a coffee person.--Cost: A half dozen was $8 and some change.  A bit on the higher side, but I have no qualms paying that for a good donut.--Atmosphere: This location has a very hip atmosphere.  There are wooden tables on the interior and the decor itself is plain yet modern.  If you picture in your mind a place that a group of hipsters would want to eat donuts at, this is it.  I wouldn't consider myself a hipster by any stretch of the term, but it's inviting and I love it.--Service: I commend Sugar Shack for employing the three members that were at the counter today.  Each of them knew their menu items and was super pleasant.  Fitting along with the Atmosphere, they also seemed pretty hip.--Overall: In my mind, Country Style has always been my RVA Gold Standard place to get a donut.  That hasn't necessarily changed as Country Style offers delicious donuts as well, but Sugar Shack has my approval.  My approval, my recommendation, all of it.  Great and hip atmosphere, great staff, and great donuts.

<review# 252,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/23/2014,1/30/2014,5,39,12,12,6>In the two and a half years I've lived in Church Hill, I take Main Street through Shockoe Bottom to get to my job, so I see the area's evolution.  I was intrigued when the dark, brown-awninged building that once held the 1800 Club started transforming into a bright, teal-awninged building to be named Sweet Teas.  "Restaurant?" I thought hopefully.  Oh, yes, indeed, restaurant.  If I drove by on weekday evenings or weekend afternoons, it was always well-populated, a good sign.  Last Saturday after a long week my husband pointed our SUV in the direction of Millie's.  Not wanting to sit outside on a cold day and seeing my opportunity, I suddenly said "I wanna go to Sweet Teas!"As has been noted in other reviews, patrons are greeted with a cheerful "Welcome to Sweet Teas!" upon entering.  It was kind of latish, after one, but there was still a good crowd.  We were seated promptly and our server, Gavin, was with us almost immediately.Sweet Teas is a good old soul food diner despite the airy pastel dining room.  If you like soul food--AND WHAT SORT OF WEIRDO ARE YOU IF YOU DON'T?--there's nothing on the menu that you won't know and you will agonize over what to order because everything sounds so tempting.  First, drinks.  Yes, I know a place called Sweet Teas does iced teas very well, but ... well, I'm not super-crazy about iced tea (although the descriptions of the peach tea intrigue me).  So we got homemade lemonade served in a Mason jar.  It was great, not too sweet or tart.  I ordered the day's special of drumsticks and fries while my husband got the fried fish with collard greens and yams.  On a whim, my husband also ordered onion rings as an appetizer.  Hey, we don't do fried food that much so why not go all out, right?  The batter-dipped onion rings were phenomenal--too hot to handle at first, absolutely amazing when we could.  Then came the entrees.  I've gotten used to rather small pieces when I order fried chicken out.  These drumsticks?  Were HUGE.  I'm positive Oven Stuffer Roasters are chopped up to make Sweet Teas' fried chicken.  Better yet, they were delicious--perfectly seasoned, moist to the bone.  The fries were fine.  My husband raved over every bite of his meal.  But I must tell you about the mimosas, since no one else has mentioned them.  We were winding down when we noticed Gavin coming around the bar with a lovely pitcher of mimosas, the pitcher rimmed with sugar and decorated with strawberries.  We were fascinated by this, to the point that I decided to order one.  Out came my sugar-rimmed strawberry-garnished glass.  I took a sip, and that innocuous-looking orange liquid slammed into my brain like a MMA fighter.  It makes Millie's Evil Keevil rum punch seem like Hawaiian Punch.  It is delicious.  It is LETHAL.  Shane, the owner, laughed in delight when she saw my reaction.  "We don't mess around with the mimosas!" she said proudly.  My husband didn't believe me until I let him sample it.  I had a stomach full of fried food and my alcohol tolerance is normally high, but I had a legitimate buzz after finishing the mimosa.  If you get a pitcher of these, either have a large group to share them with or be able to stagger back to your place, not kidding.Of course the Health Police will snipe that eating here will clog your arteries, but not everything on the menu is fried--hell, you can even get a salad if you're so inclined.  The meatloaf looks fantastic, and I saw an old standby that my southern-raised mom used to make and I haven't had in ages--rice and gravy.  Prices are very reasonable too.  Sweet Teas is an awesome addition to the growing amount of good places to eat in the Bottom.  Just watch out for the mimosas ...

The location is hidden off of Broad and automatically you can tell the appearance and decor of the restaurant is a perfect fit. By 6PM though the whole restaurant was filled with guests. Our favorite waiter from Tarrant's, Russell was there to serve us tonight, confirming we made the right choice.Drinks were the Ommegang Take the Black for my husband and their rosewater lemonade for me. The rosewater lemonade was so refreshing and unique from anything I'd tried before. We had to do an appetizer of their poutine, which is as authentic as it goes with thick cut frites, perfectly melted cheese curds, gravy, truffle oil, and crispy pork belly. We could have ordered some salads and the poutine and been sufficiently satisfied. For our entrees, my husband had the cousselet, which is duck leg confit, pork belly, sausage, white beans, braised kale, and fried sage which puts the meal together. I have to say that my 8 hour Belgian beer braised short ribs won me over though with ratatouille, truffle whipped mashed potatoes, and jus. The short ribs fell off the bone and the portion size was perfect, leaving me plenty to take home. The price point for this restaurant is higher than Tarrant's due to the quality of the food for sure but I do love the Belgian inspired menu. Even Billy Bread served at the table ensures that this place knows what it's doing and has plenty of staying power. I'd recommend coming here again for both a casual meal or a special event.

So far, I've seen a person bring in an un-neutered male (which irritated my dog so much we had to leave), a violent dog who attacked several others (none seriously, and the other owners in the park made that person leave), and assorted rude dogs who hump other dogs' faces and pick fights. However, I do think those who own skittish or small dogs should be aware of the possibility that these unwelcome dogs may be there, and would be wise to make a survey of how the dogs already in the park are behaving before bringing their dog in.

The restaurant was very busy around noon. During peak hours, expect a wait unless you call in your order ahead of time (recommended if you're in a rush). I usually order the same meal every time (pepper steak with rice and cabbage). I'm a huge fan of their pepper steak. The meat is tender and seasoned very well. The cabbage is cooked to perfection. Parking is hit of miss depending on the day and time. The service is usually fast and employees are polite. Jamaica House is a good choice for Jamaican food in Richmond.

That said, Acacia could be dropped in the middle of Manhattan and go toe to toe with the big boys. <review# 305,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/18/2012,3/11/2013,46,100,3,6,3>The Roosevelt has recently been receiving some great press and reviews, locally, regionally, and nationally. After months of festering thoughts of eating these Southern delicacies, I finally took the plunge on a weekday night. I made reservations during the daytime via an answering machine, and was promptly called back for confirmation. The restaurant itself is located at a 5-Point intersection (M Street, 25th Street, and Jefferson Avenue) in north Church Hill. The neighborhood looks like it is undergoing a renaissance of sorts, and I think having this restaurant there could be a catalyst for future redevelopment, but I must digress. We entered the restaurant, and were immediately greeted by the friendly hostess. The restaurant is smaller (about 50-70 seats), but makes up for this with its high ceilings. The menu is definitely Southern-influenced, and had many interesting dishes. Their menu is broken down into 4 categories:  snacks, appetizers, main dishes, and desserts. We decided on cornbread with honey-vanilla butter, pimento cheese with homemade potato chips, a chicken skin slider, and Southern poutine. I will say, EVERYTHING was delicious! My favorite was the Southern poutine, which is a French-Canadian dish, with a Southern spin. It was a plate of French fries, topped with pimento cheese and ham gravy (with small chunks of ham).  The cornbread, while I thought was slightly dry, was still very good, especially with the honey-vanilla butter. The fried chicken skin slider was also delicious, and had a nice kick to it from the kimchi mayo. The Roosevelt's pimento cheese is also some of the best I have tasted in my 7 years in the RVA.The Roosevelt has reasonable prices for its food, and its beer selection is very good, and inexpensive ($3.00 - $5.00). They have a full bar and have a pretty good wine list from what I saw.This place is truly a gem, and my only regret is we didn't get a slice of Coca-Cola cake. I will be back!

<review# 352,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/22/2012,3/4/2013,5,39,10,9,8>In much of the Australasian part of the Commonwealth of Britain, pies are fast food.  Neil Smith, a New Zealander who made his living cooking on pop stars' tours, met and married Nikki Price, an RVA girl.  Neil missed his Kiwi (affectionate name for New Zealanders, not the fruit) pies.  Neil decided to open a "proper pie" shop here in Richmond, setting his sights on the Church Hill storefront that once housed the dubious ice cream shop It Must Be Heaven.  It wasn't an easy journey, but with help from seed programs and a successful Kickstarter campaign, Proper Pie Co. opened its doors last month, and in that short time has immediately become a Church Hill hot spot and the rave of Richmond.When you hear the term "savory pies," don't think crappy frozen pot pies from the supermarket.  These are true pies with delectably fat-filled flaky crusts and wonderful fillings.  Love meat?  Try the mince and cheese.  Or the (OMG FRIGGIN' AWESOME) sausage rolls, Cornish pasties, steak and mushroom, chicken and kumara ... oh, hell, you won't go wrong with any of them.  Vegetarians and vegans?  You're covered too.  PPC's delicious soups of the day are always vegan and those fantastic crusts envelop fillings such as spinach, mushroom and cheese and lentil.  You can get peach Nehi and Mexican Coke there too.  Oh--did I mention there are sweet pies too?  From British favorites like treacle tart to chocolate raspberry cream and blueberry apple (among others), whatever sweet jones you have can be met.  You're guaranteed to see Neil and Nikki behind the counter when you come in--look for the shaven-headed tattooed guy and the girl with the lip ring--and they and their staff will greet you with cheerful smiles.  There is some counter seating but if you live in the neighborhood (AS I DO FOUR BLOCKS AWAY LET ME BRAAAAG) just get your pies to go, take them home, and stuff your face with pie goodness.  A couple of caveats, though--right now PPC's hours are limited to noon through 6 p.m., although I'm sure that'll be changing.  If they run out of a particular flavor of savory or sweet pie, you're not getting any that day.  See, I told you it was just a couple. With all the recent openings of places offering terrific eats, I must write an ode to my neighborhood:Dear Church Hill:You know I love living here.  I extol your virtues to pretty much everyone I meet, and when I look at the neighborhood, which is so cool that friggin' DANIEL DAY-LEWIS stayed here while he was being Abraham Lincoln for a movie, I'm like "this is so awesome!"There's just one small problem.You're trying to kill me.  I am certain of this, for why else would you inspire a New Zealand native and his Richmond-born wife to open up an amazing pie shop FOUR BLOCKS FROM MY PLACE?  Do you want me to weigh 800 pounds?  Do you want me to show up in a TLC reality show with the end tag being "the side of her house had to be dismantled to remove her body"?  I mean, seriously, there are so many fantastic places to eat popping up on the Hill that there's no possible way one can stay on any sort of diet here.Oh, all right, I'll forgive you.  AGAIN.Love,Me

<review# 361,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/20/2012,10/4/2012,14,11,,6,2>On the corner of Monroe Street and West Broad lives one of the best sandwich shops in the city. A small and modest produce market and deli, Nick's International Food Market has been a staple of Broad Street for decades. I stop by Nick's at least a few times a month for their incredible tuna sandwich on toasted wheat bread. You will be greeted by the smiling and always witty Tony, who will take your order at the back counter. Tony is the kind of guy who will remember your name and order after a few weeks of stopping by. Grab a drink and some chips and peruse the incredible assortment of spices and international ingredients while you wait. The original Nick arrived in the US in 1951 and his store is now run by his sons, Manuel and Phillip. Nick's market is the kind of place that reminds you why it's important to know your neighbors and greet strangers on the sidewalk. Not to mention, the food is great and the service is warm. I'm a big fan of the tuna sammich but I've also heard awesome things about the Greek salad with anchovies (just try it!). Lastly, if you're on a budget, a sandwich typically will only run you about $5. Stop by Nick's and support one of the last few surviving businesses that are holding down Broad Street!

<review# 395,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/4/2012,4/3/2012,114,325,6,12,8>Let me preface by saying that this is not the best Chinese food I've ever had (not by far). However, Yelp says five stars means "Woohoo! As good as it gets!". And for Richmond, this is certainly as good as it gets when it comes to Chinese. This was the first time I ate at a Chinese establishment since moving to Richmond. As a native, I have very high standards when it comes to eating at Chinese places, so I had been reluctant to eat Chinese in Richmond (a lot of places seemed like the all-too-typical Americanized fare). But after hearing such rave reviews about Peter Chang, I was excited to see what all the hubbub was about. The restaurant did not disappoint! I called ahead to make a reservation for my party of five, which was a good call because the restaurant was packed even at 8:30PM (granted, it was a Saturday night). We were seated within ten minutes.This restaurant is still very new! It's spacious, which is great for accommodating large groups (and necessary considering how much business this place is ALREADY getting). I really like the decor; it's very bright and colorful, and the butterflies hanging from the ceiling add a nice touch. The dining patrons seemed to be a mix of Caucasians and Asians; I even saw the Tan A workers/owners come to dine during my meal! You know this restaurant is legit if you can appeal to natives.I was SO excited that there was Chinese on the menu (since I don't know the names of dishes in English), and that the waitress for our table spoke Mandarin. (I have been desperately craving opportunities to speak Mandarin!) I was also ecstatic that "dishes" such as Orange Chicken and Beef w/Broccoli, although on the menu, did not feature prominently (it makes me cringe that so many people think those kinds of dishes are authentic Chinese food). I'm hoping that this will give many people the chance to experience REAL Chinese food (in Richmond at least). The variety of offerings available at Peter Chang's China Cafe will definitely allow people to branch out and try something they would never have found at "insert-name-of-Americanized-fast-food-chain-here"­! Let's talk about the food (also, see attached photos). Sichuan/Szechuan food is known for its numbing spice. While I was prepared for the worst when my table ordered Peter Chang Duck in Stone Pot (three chili symbols), the dish wasn't actually that spicy. Surprisingly, the Fish with Sour Cabbage Soup (one chili symbol) was the spiciest dish of the night. We also ordered Crispy Pork Belly (one chili), which came served in this really cool bamboo cone, Tofu with Vegetable in Clay Pot (not spicy), and Basil Eggplant (not spicy). [Sidenote: we had to ask for chopsticks and white rice.] All the dishes were excellent, and many of the other Chinese people in my party remarked that they couldn't believe we were actually dining on this kind of Chinese food in Richmond, VA! I did not have input into the selection of dishes for dinner (since my friends picked all of the dishes), so I definitely will be back to try some of the things that interest me.Service was fine (again, I was happy to be able to speak Mandarin). Our waitress, Snow, was a little ditzy at times (bringing us four glasses of water but six teacups and six bowls for our party of five), but she was very sweet and helpful throughout the meal. The $7-8 lunch special dishes seem like a bargain too. This restaurant will definitely be a huge incentive for me to make more frequent trips to Short Pump. =)FYI: For those of you not literate in Chinese, the character underneath the chili pepper in the sign is Chang (spelled "Zhang" in hanyu pinyin), Peter's surname!P.S. I just had to go in and edit my review because Yelp does not support Chinese characters. =\ What is up with that?!

You may find yourself craving it days later...And for dessert, get the profiteroles.  Not because they are adventurous (though they are, with an almost bittersweet chocolate sauce liberally drizzled on top of them) but because they are freshly made, soft and moist and slightly chewy, and filled with a delicious fresh cream.  And you deserve a reward for your adventurous choices.To be honest, no matter what you get I'm pretty sure you'll love it, because there's not a bad menu item listed...  and if you try something new and amazing, hit me up with a message and tell me about it!  I'm slowly working my way through the menu dish by dish... it' that good.

<review# 433,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/2/2012,4/24/2013,47,39,3,9,2>What this restaurant lacks in decor and elegance it gains with good food.  Very good food.  The menu boasts classic (no Olive Garden crap here) Italian dishes. There's no physical paper menus here, everything's listed on the massive chalkboard on one wall.  Can't see it?  Turn your head.  Your favorite dish has a big X on it?  They don't have it, order something else.  Forget "have it your way" hospitality, Mamma Zu has customers playing their way; of course, this can make pretentious diners feel powerless, making for one interesting customer service experience.  For me, I prefer the raw un-fluffy service and ambiance centered around good food, not fancy font menus or hand stitched table linens.  If you're open to mediocre service, no ass-kissing, and food that'll make you melt with delight, this is your place.My dining companions and I started with a few dishes. Not a fan of eggs or tuna, I made a pass for the eggs in tuna sauce ($5) but I quickly fell in love with the squid, bean, and arugula antipasti ($14).  After checking out other online thoughts and reviews, this was one cherished dish.  The fresh and peppery arugula paired with warm olive oil and mellow white beans and squid is amazing, nothing compares.  Also ordered Sweetbreads - my first experience and although a little chewy, I haven't decided a yay or nay opinion but I was impressed with the mushroom/sage/wine sauce (if you think sweetbreads is sugary bread, get the real deal here). I was also pleased they serve one of my favorite nostalgic brews, Abita Purple Haze.Main course are all served family style. After much deliberation we settled on the Branzino ($23), Lamb Sausage ($17), spaghetti & meatballs ($15), and Rockfish ($22).  A quick rundown... bone-in fish freaks me out so I passed on the Branzino, the Rockfish was incredibly mild and buttery, Spaghetti & Meatballs was simple and lovely, and the Lamb Sausage won my heart.  The lamb was spicy and full of sexy flavors (yeah, flavors can be sexy) and was paired with creamy polenta and warm white beans.  The flavors was comforting and humble.Mamma Zu isn't one of Richmond's top restaurant for nothing, this place is an experience and the food is exceptional.  For me, it solidifies the ongoing admiration I have for local eateries and the servers, cooks, and team that delivers authentic deserving food.

<review# 449,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/23/2013,6/7/2013,46,109,2,3,2>Whenever the Greek Festival rolls around, I hearken back to the good old days (barely ten years ago) when the crowds there were manageable, the parking was tolerable and the er, um, ah clientele was a tad bit more refined.  Well, the past few years, we've tried, oh how we've tried to go to the festival but after waiting in incredibly long lines and hearing about shortages of food choices...even on day one...we have found ourselves saying...why?  You go, of course, mostly for the food and drink...well I've found a place in the West End that will give you that authentic vibe without the hassle...YEAR 'ROUND!  It is Greek 4U, an unassuming Greek place at Pump and Patterson Avenues.Now, in the interest of full disclosure, I have this place on high "potential to close" alert.  The adjacent businesses have pulled out, including a CVS and rug store, and not much is left of the old Patterson and Pump guard save Rare Old Times.  So this would be one of those places I would URGE my West End peeps to try if only to give it a chance to thrive in this tough economy.Grape leaves, spanikopita, souvlaki, you name it, we got it, partly on the appetizer sampler and in entrees, and we were not disappointed.  They also have a great wine selection, reasonably priced, and a side room that seats 30 with a large mural of Santorini, one of the most breathtaking places on Earth.I think the only drawback was the absence of a kid's menu, although there is enough choice for even the most finicky eater.  However, the pasta dish put in front of my son could have fed him for a week (and did).The salad ingredients were fresh, the sandwiches were stuffed with meat and perfectly seasoned.  We are going to go back and try wines and desserts for sure, but for now, I am quite happy not having to wait until June to visit the Greek islands, because Greek 4U brings them back to me in a satisfying and reasonably-priced manner.FYI - Greek 4U is closed on Sundays...
<review# 450,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/1/2013,6/6/2013,29,56,2,3,2>Stopped by here for a Friday lunch break from work.  We were actually headed to the Hogshead Cafe next door but there were a number of people waiting outside and the Greek Islands had tables open. That's really all I'm asking for.However, I think the food was at least equal to or above par with other Greek restaurants in the metro area.  Their "Village Salad" is actually what a Greek Salad is meant to be with no lettuce to accompany the chopped vegetables, olives, pepperoncini, and feta cheese (with onions and anchovies on request ... yes, please!).  A "Greek Salad" is also included that has lettuce which I'm sure is there because of everyone ordering a greek salad and expecting lettuce. Score one point for traditional Greek.I noticed that the avgolemono soup is just called "chicken & rice" on their menu but it's close to the traditional with the lemon served on the side instead of a major flavor component in the soup.  Still tasty.I got the pastichio and it is easily the best I have had in Richmond and mainly because the "greek meat sauce" that they listed on the menu was really ground beef cooked just right and seasoned with a great spice blend.  Plus just enough of the homemade béchamel sauce to support the dish without overwhelming it as most places will do.I also got a taste of someone else's gryo meat (lamb) and it was on par with most every other gyro you can get anywhere else.  The tzatziki sauce that came with it, however, was thick and bold. One of the best I've had. Again, I couldn't care less if that means it wasn't authenticate ... it was great.Plus we couldn't have asked any more from our waitress who provided excellent service for the whole meal.  Glad we stumbled upon it and will certainly keep it on the list of places to try for dinner.

<review# 452,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/9/2014,7/19/2014,6,31,2,10,3>MEAT MEAT MEAT!!! That's a little song I sing when I think about the delicious food here at Deep Run Roadhouse. It pays homage to my 3 favorite BBQ options that I have tried  at DRR that inspire me to make the 25 minute drive across town. Here are my thoughts about each in order of my level of addiction:1) Brisket: The brisket is served sliced instead of chopped as it is at another hot BBQ place in town. The juicy slices often include a small ribbon of of fat (for the uninitiated this is a good thing (No, it's not tough fat. It's melt in your mouth, buttery fat). Each order also includes a portion of charred -and also slightly fatty- burnt ends. Mm mm mmmm.2) Smoked Sausage: I salivated when I typed that. Seriously. I believe they make and smoke the sausage in house. The flavor is outrageous and I'll guarantee that it's the juiciest sausage you've ever had. You might not be convinced that juicy is something you want in a sausage, but it is. Trust me. Be sure to put some of their spicy BBQ sauce on it for good measure.  My only critique would be that the skin could stand to have a bit more "snap."3) Chopped Pork- The texture and flavor are spot on. Some places mince their pork to a point that it's hardly recognizable as meat, but DRR chops it down to the perfect size. I prefer the vinegary Carolina style sauce for this option. Of course, a BBQ restaurant can't be sustained on good meat alone. Their two sauces options (provided in bottles on every table) are a great compliment to anything you order here. You can choose from a spicy option that is is thinner and has a little more tang than you get at other places, or the vinegary Carolina style. My passion is getting the best of me and this is getting a bit long, but I just need to also mention that the sides here are top notch. You really can't go wrong. The potato wedges are perfectly crispy, the southwest slaw gets you the best of Texas caviar and coleslaw in one dish, the jalapeno mac and cheese and a good twist on a BBQ classic... I could keep going but you should be in your car by now!

I had a choice of Pastor meat, Chicken, Pork or Beef.  I chose Pastor Meat.  I watched her HAND make the Corn Tortilla and it was not something out of a package.  The thickness of the Tortilla was about 3 times the thickness of a regular Tortilla.   She fixed 3 of these and cooked them on the open grill.  While waiting for my food to be cooked, I found where they keep the drinks and I saw Coco Cola in a bottle which came from Latin America.  No screw off cap as you have to use the OLD Fashion Bottle opener.  Boy this brought back memories...  They had American Coke here in the case, however they import Coca Cola which is bottled down South.  So, I decided to go all the way... 100% Latin Food!Upon getting my Zopes, I could not believe my eyes in the size.  At first she gave me a plastic fork and knife, however this was just not going to cut the mustard in being able to eat this meal... so she gave me some regular utensils.   Upon speaking with the Owner, she said the place had been here for 9 years!  I was shocked as I have driven past this small Latin Grocery store many times and NEVER knew there was a small Mom & Pop style restaurant in this place.  The only drawback was how she served the Zopes... she had a sheet of Restaurant Paper on the plate which she placed the Zopes.  However the sauces from the food soaked into the paper and I had to pick some of the paper from the food to eat.  Next time, I will ask for her not to put the paper on the plate.  I suggest that you do the same.   Anyway,  this Latino Village Restaurant is a MUST try as it is a REAL Jewel which has been hidden from most of us for many years.  I plan to go back even though it is a limited menu.... so what!  The food is good and "HOME COOKED" !   See you there Amigo!    :-)

<review# 470,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/26/2012,6/9/2012,114,325,2,5,3>It was a friend's birthday as well as the end of our M1 year, so twelve of us came to Mamma Zu to celebrate! First of all, I want to explain that Mamma Zu has a strict policy regarding large groups. You can only make reservations for parties of six or more, and your entire party must be present prior to being seated. Additionally, if your party does not show up within 15 minutes past your reservation, your reservation is canceled (just make sure everyone arrives on time!). When you do have a large group, food is served family style. While you can order as many appetizers individually as you want, you are only allowed to order four entrees. You can then specify how many portions of each entree you would like to feed the group. A gratuity was not automatically added on despite having a large group, so after we added a tip ourselves the total bill came out to over $300 dollars. Considering that we had a group of twelve, a bill in that amount is understandable, although each person ended up paying $31, so this restaurant is definitely on the pricier side (granted, we did treat the birthday girl and split her share among the remaining guests, but that only added about $3 to each person's contribution). Our group chose lamb shank, roasted duck, eggplant parmesan, and squid ink pasta. We ordered three servings of each dish except for just two orders of lamb. This was plenty of food for the twelve of us, and we even had a little left over. Additionally, our complimentary bread was refilled SEVERAL times while we were waiting for our main course, so you can definitely get your fill from that (there are small bottles of olive oil and balsamic vinaigrette on each table). The bread, although not warm, is excellent with a nice chewy inside texture.The dishes themselves were delicious. The duck with grilled polenta was my favorite! It was very similar to the duck dish with polenta that I had at Edo's Squid. This duck came pre-cut into small slices, which made it very easy to share. The meat was succulent and cooked to just the right tenderness, then soaked in a rich brown sauce. The polenta was also nice and crunchy on the outside.The squid ink pasta was my next favorite. It was served with shrimp and crabmeat, and was very popular among our group (it was the first dish to be finished). It bears mentioning that you can't really taste the squid ink itself; basically, all the squid ink goes to making the incredibly dark-colored pasta. I was anticipating some squid ink in the pasta sauce as well, but the seafood in this dish was cooked in a tomato-based sauce instead. Nevertheless, it was tasty!The eggplant parmesan and lamb shank were ok, but not particularly to my liking. The breaded and friend eggplant was not as crunchy as I would have liked for something fried, and the sauce had a strange aftertaste of tea leaves for me. As for the lamb, while we ordered only two shanks, there was a TON of meat. The lamb was cooked thoroughly enough that the meat practically fell off the bone (no knife was served with the dish, yet the meat was able to be scraped off with the fork and spoon provided). While this is generally a good finding, I am simply not a big lamb person, and the sauce that drenched the lamb was not particularly interesting. The lamb shank was by no means bad-tasting; it just wasn't anything special in my opinion.Our waitress was super friendly and down-to-earth, providing excellent service throughout the entire meal. The restaurant itself is fairly small (which might partly account for the strict reservations policy), but it is cozy and reminiscent of a small-town deli or family kitchen. The restaurant does keep it somewhat dark inside though, with candles supplementing the minimal overhead lighting. There are no paper menus, so all the options are written on a large blackboard on the wall. Mamma Zu is tucked away on Pine St. with minimal commercial stores/restaurants nearby. The exterior is also very unassuming, lacking bright lights or a clear sign; the green front door at the corner does not stand out either, so make sure you look carefully because this place is easily overlooked! Nonetheless, Mamma Zu serves up some excellent Italian food! =)

with.)Atmosphere: Situated in one of those shopping plaza type arrangements, the external of the building makes you feel like you'll be walking into a tiny place.  It's actually not that tiny and in Italian feel.Service: When we arrived there were only a few people dining and the waitress was very attentive.  Throughout the next half an hour, nearly all of the tables filled up and customers came different kind of feeling than to be blown off by rude wait staff as she was trying her heart out and was super nice throughout the whole experience, so I can't knock her for trying her heart out. getting a great pizza.  We're still new to the Richmond scene, so I can't really rate Capriccios against local competitors, but it sure beats the pizza sauce out of Papa John's.  I'm sure we'll be trying some more pizza from around Richmond in the upcoming months, but I do expect to return to Capriccio's and order another pizza.

It is not too far from the playgrounds - if you like a bit of a walk to get the blood flow goin'! This is a great park hidden in the city that many do not often visit. For those who have relatives in town that like to bike or just want a beautiful walk, look no further than Forest Hill Park!
<review# 512,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/5/2013,1/23/2013,35,126,3,8,4>For those of you who frequent downtown, you likely know this place as Becky's Diner @ 1st & Cary.  Becky's has been in RVA for many years and served exclusively as a breakfast & lunch spot.  As you people also know, they have been in & out of business a number of times over the last 5 years.  With new management (again) they appear to have the financing to stay open, maintaining the breakfast & lunch crowd with plans to redefine the place as a new night time hot spot for the over 25 crowd.The tacky yet quaint pink front facade with the 50s diner look has been replaced by a sleek & sexy blue color pallet with black awnings embossed with their logo & dark tinted windows.  And while the limo-tinted windows make this place slightly uninviting, perhaps even intimidating to walk up to if you're looking for a place to eat; I can assure you this place is not some shifty strip club (damn-it).They've made a good attempt at refining the dining area by completely opening the place up.  Gone is the space-consuming lunch-bar that congested the space... It has been replaced by a large number of contemporary-styled booths & dining tables.  All the lighting has been replaced by sexy pendant lighting over each booth with minimal overhead lighting for the tables which occupy the middle of the dining room. The place is filled with TVs playing sports & news which makes it a great place to decompress while staying connected to current events over lunch.As your make your way to the bathrooms, while I'm not sure this was the intention, they have created a space which can make long lines to the crapper a little more enjoyable with large home theater recliners & a flat panel TV... of course I imagine on busy nights this also creates a lot of congestion getting there.Additionally, they have replaced the 2 apartments on the 2nd & 3rd floors with a soon-to-open billiard area, 2 lounge areas, bar & private VIP room.For those of you who've dined @ Becky's over the past few years, you will still see lots of familiar faces... at least during the day time hours (not been here @ night).  You will also see that many of their down-home southern-style dishes have not been replaced on the menu.  In fact, for all intents & purposes, the only thing which seems to have changed here is the name, front facade, interior & addition of a few dinner-related menu items.As far as the food... myself & co-workers eat here quite often for lunch; normally take out.  Generally speaking, the food is good.  It's typically well seasoned American staple dishes.  From sandwiches to daily plate specials I've had, they're always yummy.  I'd say most everything I've had here is homemade; and sometimes this is more evident than others as the seasoning always varies a little.  This place serves more like what you expect from a good home-cook rather than a chef who can pull off carbon copies consistently.The staples for us are as follows: -- The Cary 100 burger... which we add an over-medium fried egg to.  A note, the description says it's on Texas Toast... We can only assume they've not experienced real Texas Toast.  They seem to think it's regular-sliced white bread that gets buttered than toasted.  So don't be surprised when you don't get 2" thick toast.-- Friday Fried Chicken... Check you heart & blood-pressure medicine @ the door, their fried chicken is  the only thing you should be eating on Friday's.  While the hand-made batter is sometimes (way) over salted, it's still bangin'.  -- Country-fried steak is certainly noteworthy although some times they come out severed with a chicken or brown gravy rather than white sausage gravy. (if you ask for white they might give you chicken gravy)... just warning you.-- Collard Greens are almost as good as the ones my grandmother used to make.  Cooked perfectly; not mushy from sitting in water too long.  Appear to be seasoned with apple vinegar, ham hock & love.-- Mashed Potatoes are not as good as mine (who's are?) but they are fresh-made with potatoes, not creamy but not chunky... guessing they make 'em with chicken broth as they are too light to be milk-basedBecause I want to see them succeed, a little constructive criticism never hurts...Breakfast:  Same as Karens, 3rd St, McLeans, River City... except $1-$3 more per plate.   Redefine your breakfast with presentation & innovation or get your prices inline with others if you want to grow this business beyond the regs you have now.Service: They're VERY NICE & on basic task but lack professionalism/personality.  I believe service was Beckys' Achilles-heel.  A lot of $ has been spent on cosmetics but your service doesn't seem to reflect your new identify.Kitchen: I can't think of a single time I've ordered that the kitchen wasn't out of something I wanted.Takeout: While laughable to us; for new clients, the forgetfulness will determine if they order ages

<review# 541,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/10/2013,1/11/2014,135,66,2,8,2>***Drinks Only Review***I had two delicious drinks with friends here last night and wanted to share this with fellow Yelpers.  Based on the drinks, I can't wait to try the food!Overall - this is a great bar/restaurant in the ever emerging Jackson Ward.  I'm going to be bitter I don't live there in a few years given all they have going on (see also Mama J's, Gallery5, etc.).  It has a we-care-about-food-and-drink vibe, but not a pretentious vibe...very comfortable.  They have vinyl records playing that the bar tender changes out - good music that I hadn't heard before.  The windows offer plenty of light.  Really, a great place for day drinking or, as we did, a summer happy hour.I had the Honey Badger - "a spicy summer punch that don't care."  It's dry rum, apple brandy, lime, passionfruit, jalapeno, and honey.  It was delicious with a hell of a jalapeno bite.  The ice cube (so glad for this) was made to fit the rocks glass.  Very thoughtful cocktail.I followed this up with The Last Rickey - "a tart & dry long drink version of The Last Word" with gin, chartreuse, maraschino, lime and soda.  Again with an ice cube to perfectly fit the Tom Collins glass.  This one I wouldn't have again, but it was surely another very thoughtful cocktail.  There are at least a dozen more I wanted to try...The bartender knows his stuff.  We asked a few questions and got a load of good info back from him.  I also like the fact that he was dressed pretty casually - I think he had on a soccer jersey.  Finally of note is the menus are put in old books like a photo album (with the seasonal offering listing serving as the photo - no actual photos...this isn't Cheesecake Factory).  It's a nice twist, but now you can act like you've been there before by not looking as surprised as I did about this quirk.  Can't wait to try the food and bring more friends here!  For other great cocktail locations see 525 at the Berry Burk, Heritage, The Roosevelt, and (I hear) Dutch & Company.  Glad Saison is in RVA!

It was perfect for me and my friend to share.  I left stuffed and with food for lunch.I am happy to report that I never felt rushed at dinner.  I was worried that since this is such a busy, trendy place that they would want to turn the table quickly.  I enjoyed catching up with my friend who I had not seen in a couple of months.  Katherine checked on us frequently, and I never felt pressure to hurry up and leave.I had a great experience at Stella's. It is loud, so be prepared to talk loudly to have a conversation with your fellow diners at your table.  I can't wait to go back.
