<review# 635,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/22/2011,3/20/2012,14,73,2,7,6>Okay...First of all, I have to start off by saying that there are those in an uproar about this place not being completely "authentic Cuban food" and that the food is inconsistent.  As far as the inconsistency goes, I have no logical argument with which to dispute such claims, yet, I have not had either poor food or service here; rather, both have been wonderful.As for the authenticity of the food, I wish to point out one thing: this is a business.  Despite whatever you feel should or should not be done, and regardless of any single person's opinion as to what constitutes authenticity or not, a business will do what is necessary to stay...in...business.Admittedly, New York has better Cuban food, and Miami (Little Cuba) is home to what is arguably the best Cuban food you will get in the U.S., but that is due to the high concentration of Cubans!  Here in Richmond, VA, Kuba Kuba is still in business, therefore, they must be doing something right.  Keep in mind as well that businesses only survive as long as they are progressive and willing to change.  No place is this rule more necessary than in the culinary world.The menu has items on it that are classically progressive, however, some items are still done the old fashioned way, as it has been proven to be the best way.  The sandwiches are good, the entrees are ample, and everything else I've had is, well...quite tasty.  My wife (who is Latina and a native of Miami) has thoroughly enjoyed everything that she has ordered as well.  The service has always been good, if not great, and the owner makes you feel very welcome.The spot is intimate, like a lot of Richmond locations, but there are several booths and a bar in addition to tables.  The parking is...well, it's the city.  Expect to walk.Oh, and in closing, there is one additional note.In America, respect is thought to be earned, not given.  In Latin culture, it is the other way around.  Hospitality, as well, is a way of life.  You may find that you will get better service if you keep these things in mind, as you will have shown your hosts that you respect them, and appreciate their hospitality.In the end, if you are looking for a recommendation, you've got it.  I believe this place is a hit.

<review# 658,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/28/2013,11/5/2013,89,171,3,6,3>I've spent quite a while staring at the review box trying to come up with a witty intro or fun way to tie into a review, but after about 10 minutes, all I can say is that TT Lounge is damn good.--Food: All the boba tea I've had in Richmond thus far has been in the form of either a slushie or a smoothie.  Not that it's a bad thing, but I've been searching for a more "tea"-like beverage and TT Lounge has just that.  They have Slushies too though, so if you want that, you can have that as well!Per suggestion of a fellow Yelper who I believe knows a thing or two about boba, I went with the Milk Tea, specifically Mango.  I'm not sure I've had milk tea before but the taste was great.  Slightly creamy and slightly sweet, it's sort of what I'd imagine drinking the offspring of a cup of tea and a creamsicle would taste like, in a non-gross way.  (Not that I condone the consumption of offspring!)  Alright, maybe that's not quite a good analogy, but the drink was darn good.  If you like a non-strong tea flavor and a non overwhelming milk flavor, give it a try.I have been told and saw that TT Lounge uses powder tea instead of actually brewing their tea, which to me isn't a big issue, but is true in reviews that knock it for that.  To me, if it tastes good, it tastes good.  And this was good.Also worth mentioning is the consistency of the boba (tapioca pearls).  A couple places I've tried around here either had really firm boba or boba that was hard in the middle.  I'm not sure if those other places just aren't cooking it long enough or what, but the boba in TT Lounge is far superior.  It's chewy but not hard and tastes fantastic.  It also fits through the straws better than some other places in RVA.--Cost: A Milk Tea and Slushie, both with boba, came to about $8.50 I think.  Not the cheapest, but like another review mentions, it's worth the extra dollar for good boba.--Atmosphere: The interior has some mismatched furniture and a variety of types of tables to sit at.  Seems like what you'd end up with if you went to a gently used furniture sale and bought what you thought would fit in an area you had to fill.  Is that a problem?  Not at all.  Does it catch you offguard when you walk in, not expecting that?  A little.  Side note, parking is a little hard during the busy part of a school day, but manageable.--Service: People have mentioned the rudeness of the staff here, but I didn't notice.  I will agree with anyone saying that they weren't bursting with friendliness, but they weren't mean or disrespectful in any way.  Drinks were made and presented within a few minutes.--Overall: I have yet to find another place that offers Tea / Milk Tea varieties of Boba in RVA.  I'm sure there are <review# 676,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/29/2014,2/5/2014,125,397,19,24,15>Wow!  Talk about a thrifter's dream!  I thought that thrift stores like this didn't exist in Richmond.  Boy was I wrong!  When you browse the racks at Fan Tastic thrift, it seems like you're at a store in a much bigger city.  You find actual good stuff, which, unfortunately, is quite the rarity around here.  You will find top brands at great prices and lots of new stuff.Yes, this place is tough.  True, it's a bit cut-throat, but only the strong survive.  If you can pull through, you will find lots of gems.  I usually have the hardest time, even at thrift stores with better selection, because of my size.  Everything's usually 10, 12, and maybe 8.  I found tons of options in my size here!  I left with the most clothing I've ever left with from a single store.  I found multiple brand new items, and the rest definitely looked new.  I  even got my usual wonderful thrift store cookbook find. Yippiee!!  There is even a decent selection of accent furniture here.Just a warning, if you are not a seasoned thrifter, you will find yourself frustrated, so I will give you a helpful rundown of some thrift  store no-nos that will help you have a more successful, less frustrating visit.  Rule #1 Never, ever point or discuss something you like loudlyYou like it, you pick it up, even if you are undecided.  If you point, it will be gone as soon as you turn around.  I guarantee it!  If little Jane Doe didn't like it before, she now loves it because you just detailed aloud how great of a find it is and why.Rule #2 Wear something simple.  I recommend leggings or very close-fitting skinny jeans with a tank with shoes that can be easily removed.  Don't forget the socks, for goodness sake!  If it's cold, put an easy-to-remove sweater over your tank.  This allows you to try on things over your clothing very easily.  Ain't no fittin' room 'round here, sistah.Rule #3 Ditch the cart.  It's bulky, it's big, it's annoying.  Yes, they have them, but no, they don't fit through the aisles very well.Rule #4 Got a whiney man?  Leave him at home or send him off with the boys.  You will need time to shop this place well, and he will get antsy.  The last thing you need is an annoying buzzing in your ear about how it's time to leave after you've only looked over two aisles.  You have to check the entire store before leaving.  Got kids?  Send 'em to their aunt's house.  That's what she's there for.Rule #5 Bring one friend with you who is NOT the same size as you and who will be honest.  Something about the thrill of the chase makes you think you'll absolutely love stuff that you really won't just because it's such a great deal.Rule #6 Go early.  It gets crowded and, remember, you're trying on stuff in the aisles.  Beating the crowds is important.  Rule #7 If know you are lazy, stay at home.  Thrifting is not for the lazy.  It's for those who don't mind putting in work to find their buried treasure.  If you are too lazy to work, you'll waste your gas and your time coming here, and you'll leave empty-handed.And why is this place missing a star?  Well, no fitting rooms and super tight aisles and no returns (again, all reasons why this is not the place for newbs).  Not to mention the fact that that ol' thrift store stench is in full effect in here!

All the fun of a regular cupcake but with a label on it that makes me feel like I'm not as much of a fatass as I really am. Presentation wise, the cupcakes are adorable. They never seem to get impatient and are willing to answer all your dumb questions. On top of it, they're always smiling. Prices are cheaper than what I've encountered. I don't know the price off hand because I don't keep my receipts, because who needs a receipt for a cupcake? But I wanna say it's in the upper $2 range per cupcake. I don't wanna give an exact number and be wrong so I'll be sure to double check tomorrow. Yes. Tomorrow.Pearls' also offers brownies and other baked goods. There are tables lined with apothecary jars full of sweets, too.The store is quaint, with ample seating. Parking isn't a hassle either. While most of it's street parking, it's never too difficult to find a spot.Pearl's has my vote for best cuppys in Richmond.

Overall, this place is one of the best places to pick up food in Richmond. They recently expanded their hours to be open until 8, so those of you Church Hill folks out there who hadn't been able to go after work, you can now rejoice. Go to Proper Pie, revel in its wonder, and support a local business that definitely deserves it.

The peanut satay sauce is thick and slightly spicy and the pad see ew served with chinese broccoli.Overall, not a bad addition to the Thai scene at all. Prices are good as well: for two entrees and two appetizers the bill came to under $30. Plus the 30% off that they are currently advertising and it was under $20.Service was nice and friendly both times.A note: It did say on the door something about being closed in between lunch and dinner. I'll have to check next time I'm there but I think it was around 3ish on weekdays and 4ish on the weekends.

<review# 818,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/21/2014,6/23/2014,80,45,4,6,4>A raucous round of applause for the Chef at The Magpie for creating a truly unique and phenomenal Gastropub experience. At The Magpie you will find yourself engulfed in a rustic-modern experience and dining on traditionally hearty meals that look like true pieces of artwork.As with many quality restaurants these days, The Magpie prides itself on leveraging the best of local ingredients from participating farms. However, what makes it unique is the flair at which dishes are presented and the palate entangling flavor combinations on it's menu.The only major disruption in our otherwise stellar dining experience was the chewing-on-grass-like flavors of the baby radish, cheese, and turnip* amuse-bouche served prior to our menu; however, it did serve a palate cleansing approach and a tribute to fresh, farm ingredients.To start our meal we elected to try the house made sausage and the charred asparagus appetizers. The sausage was a meaty, flavorful, and spicy bite with a smoking hot interior and a perfectly crisp outer casing adding a depth of texture to the bite. It was paired beautifully with an aromatic and strong mixture of bleu cheese, pistachio, and mint adding a nice basic, cooling note to the dish. Wonderfully prepared!The asparagus, normally a bland side dish, stood on its own as a small plate capable of being a meal in-and-of itself. An abundance of flavor accompanied the dish in the form of delicate roasted wild mushrooms, spring onion cream, and a manchego crumb.Prior to our main entrees, a nice warm cup of asparagus and goat cheese soup arrived at the table. Seated by the window on a mild day, the soup was the perfect warm dish to keep our stomachs looking for more. Simple, yet delicious - the balance and consistency of the soup had us wondering if we could order a handful of mason jars to go like I do at my grandma's farm in West Virginia.Our entrees, in my mind, are the essence of what The Magpie seeks to exhibit in it's locally grown, locally sourced, hearty and rustic southern meal experience - pulled rabbit with a gravy and cherry lacquered duck breast. If I could put Richmond on a plate, it would be these dishes.These were both unique dishes, with depth in flavor, complexity in design, and a bit of a confusing harmony of flavors. We went head first into accepting the confusion, as it was artfully planned and skillfully crafted.The richness in flavor of the cherry lacquer and the deep fatty flavor of the duck breast met wonderfully with an extremely acidic ramp pesto. The pesto, a delicious bite on its own, hits your senses like a slap in the face. The unique twist, a candy brittle infused with rosemary adding another aromatic note to the dish and a delightfully sweet note to be savored with the duck meat.As for the pulled rabbit (think pulled pork), the gravy was actually (I believe) a smoked fennel puree which added a homey flavor to the rabbit. Again, uniquely paired, was a sweet granola which added an oddly enjoyable texture and flavor contrast to the dish. We actually swapped plates. Myself giving rave reviews for the in-your-face flavors of the duck and my significant other speaking the same for the light-and-simple notes of the  pulled duck.We were both wonderfully impressed by our experience and have placed The Magpie above most, if not all, of the other eateries we've frequented in Richmond, VA!Notes:Our desserts were quality, but not reviewed in this post.Apart from the baby radish, I did not write down the ingredients. <review# 844,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/16/2012,9/20/2012,8,33,,5,3>Hollywood Cemetery has shaped my view of cemeteries for as long as I can remember. It's beautiful and peaceful, historic and a little spooky. The hallowed grounds serve as the final resting place for a host of notable Virginians including former presidents, Tyler and Monroe. There's a massive confederate monument dedicated to the fallen soldiers and leaders; President, Jefferson Davis, and J.E.B. Stuart are also buried here. The winding paths and towering trees curve through beautiful mausoleums and other examples of Gothic architecture. There are a number of notable grave sites that are must sees such as a dog standing watch over a child's grave. The most distinguishing aspect of Hollywood Cemetery is that it is more like an enchanting park overlooking the James River that just happens to be a cemetery. Artificial flowers are banned but families are encouraged to plant living flowers and shrubbery to remember their loved ones. Water spigots are sprinkled throughout to encourage this as well. As a child, I visited the cemetery on field trips but I also grew up knowing my relatives were buried there. As an adult I've found that it is a truly special place to go and think, and to remember those whom you've lost.

<review# 848,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/2/2012,9/16/2012,19,79,3,5,3>For All You Fellow Nature Lovers.... Belle Isle has many hidden secrets and tons of wildlife, alongside its trendy hang out spot "Dead Rock" . Next time your in the area, take a break from the usual guitar playing and festivities at the hang out and walk a few yards east to "Hollywood Rapid"  on a good day you might see several Great Blue Heron fishing along the rocks, or take a hike over to the "Dry Side" and try to find the rock that looks like a foot, complete with painted toe nails,  watch out for copper heads in the banks, but if you lucky you might find a Red Bellied Water snake which is quite the spectacle. Don't forget to look up you are almost guaranteed to see some Osprey , along with Bald Eagle and Broad Winged Hawk circling the waters on any part of the isle depending on the season and your luck of coarse. For those just going to cool off in the summer, I suggest getting some water shoes, there is glass from broken beer bottles and such in the water and you wont see it before it cuts you. Again when your walking across the walking bridge look up^ if your too consumed by the view below you will miss the Barn Swallows nesting beneath the bridge above you. Enjoy the beauty there is much to be seen. *On a personal note i would dare not swim on the south side of the isle where it connects to the "Dry Side" dam. I have seen many a copper head crossing stream on the tiny islands just upstream from there, stick to the places with more active rapids where it is harder for them to fish.

The chips and dip were a disappointment (stale chips and what seemed like salsa from a jar), and I didn't really dig the vegetarian chicken nuggets. We loved the corn nuggets and sweet potato fries though, and the spring rolls were good!For our entrees, my boyfriend ordered the vegetarian pho and it was so flavorful! We were both shocked at how rich the broth was for not having any flavor from meat. The only complaint he had was that there wasn't more of it! I went with the vegetarian banh mi combo, which came with not only the sandwich, but a small bowl of pho broth, sweet potato fries, and vegan coleslaw. The coleslaw was very interesting, it was made mainly with cashew nuts and some type of dressing mixed with shredded carrots. Sound really weird, but I couldn't get enough of it! Everything was amazing. I really didn't think I'd love it as much as I did! The combo is definitely the best bang for your buck, you get so much for only a couple dollars more than the pho on its own. We were both very full after our meals, but nothing stopped me and my sweet tooth from ordering a couple desserts to go to enjoy later. I think what really attracted me to the desserts were that they were Vietnamese specialties I hadn't had in a while, and seeing them listed on the menu made me long for them! We ordered the corn and sweet rice with coconut cream as well as the black-eyed peas and sweet rice with coconut cream. They were both just what I was expecting! Very well made and just delicious. Being quite the carnivore myself, trust me when I say this place is worth it for those wary of the green!

I despise peas, so this app wasn't very good to me. The Shiitake-Leek Tikka was very good. Garlic Naan...YUM! The cucumber yogurt dip that came with the bread was a fantastic clash of flavors that just worked very well together. It only had 2 scallops, which was fine, would have liked to see 1 or 2 more though.  But the lump crab meat in the Nigella-Mace-Tomato sauce was amazing. Put the mixture on the rice that is served with it and your taste-buds will be in flavor heaven!!!  I of course couldn't eat it all because of all the app taste testing I did, so I had more than half left over for lunch the next day. It heated very well in the microwave and tasted just as good which was surprising to me, a very tasty surprise! :-)  I did try the Rara Lamb Curry as well, I didn't particularly like this. It was very spicy and the flavors just didn't blend well for me. He really liked it though.The host/server was a very pleasant man that was very happy to explain most of the menu to the table and assist with menu choices. He was very knowledgable about where the different dishes came from in regards to what state in India. He even recommended an off-menu meal to one person with our party which was nice of him. He also was great about explaining to another party member which dishes were vegetarian and offered information differentiating from vegan dishes which is simply amazing because not many places in Richmond are so accomodating or informed about different dietary needs. This just added to the entire meal experience and makes me want to go back. We were never rushed, and the servers were rather attentive.  This has no doubt been the best restaurant experience I have had in Richmond in the 6 years I've lived here.
<review# 857,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/2/2013,3/31/2013,46,109,2,4,3>This is one of those places that I am sure that my review, whether good or bad, really won't make a difference to those that have read the reviews, seen the TV shows, or probably have eaten the food before.  But allow me to weigh in...this is as close to a Park Slope joint in Richmond as I have been to.  The smell hits you as you round the corner, and then you see the patiently waiting masses outside.  No bar inside, no lounge...The dining area is as big as my living room, with approximately a dozen tables of varying sizes, most big enough to accommodate a group of four or five, but if you are a large group, forget it unless you rent the place out or go with at least an hour to wait outside.  And located about a block away from the VCU Bookstore and the Siegel Center, I guess you could put your name down, disappear for a half hour and come back without missing a beat.And you will wait...we went off peak, we waited, we went for lunch, we waited, we went for dinner, we waited.  You are almost waiting for them to annex the townhouse next door before you go back.  But I digress...the important question is...IS THE FOOD WORTH THE WAIT?  The answer is yes.  The food is fresh, delicious, and, this is the most important part, unique.  Yes, their signature food item consists of sandwiches basically, so what's the big deal?  The deal is in the details, like putting granny smith apples with chicken livers and slaw-er-shredded cabbage.  Peach chutney and banana ketchup with blackened chicken.  And let's not forget the bread, crisp french baguette that is crusty but enjoyably chewable, and a fine compliment to the ingredients.  We ordered four half-battleships for four people, way too much food, but the fun was in the sampling.  If two or more want the same sandwich, certainly get the whole boat.  But plan on taking some home, especially if you sample one of their ridiculously creative desserts. The wait notwithstanding, this is the place to take an out-of-towner who may doubt Richmond's pedigree as a foodie destination.  So why the four stars instead of five?  Well, there needs to be some urgency among the serving staff and the guests to eat and not linger, and there is none.  You wanna sit in the window and stare at the cold hungry masses yearning to eat a battleship?  Go right ahead...no one will stop you.  The food takes a while understandably as it is fresh as fresh gets, but once the food is wrapped, the drinks finished, the desserts sampled, the coffee sipped, and the stares from the waiting throng beginning to turn to scowls, get me my damn check just a WEE bit faster, thanks.  I don't fault anyone for wanting to enjoy their dinner but folks, lets give at least half a thought to those that are waiting, and expedite the paying process a bit.  A small bit of concern goes a long way.  The Black Sheep is all you've heard about, but be prepared to press your face up against the glass and be an outsider looking in.  At least for a little while.  Or call the takeout angel and bring your battleships home!  Yes, they taste just as good, and you can avoid uncomfortable stares and frostbitten toes.

A wonderful meal!

<review# 882,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/31/2013,2/12/2013,36,193,2,4,3>Addis was my first experience with Eithiopian food, and it was a phenomenal culinary adventure.  Food - top notch.  Service - slow, but friendly.  Atmosphere - very mellow until the band started setting up and blaring loud music as a warm up.  My advice is to either go early, or not on a night with a band, so you can spend time enjoying the food and your party's company.  Because the food is delicious!I was able to sample a variety of the traditional Eithiopian fare, including the three appetizers.  The Katenya was my favorite - crispy and flavorful.  I enjoyed the sambussas as well, and while the tomato fit-fit was tasty, the texture takes some getting used to.In attempt to sample as much Ethiopian food as possible, I ordered the pick three vegetarian platter, with the yeabesha gomen (collards), denech alicha wot (potatoes and carrots), and misir wot (spiced red lentils).  The potatoes were by far my favorite, although the other two dishes were good as well.  Although Ethiopian food is meant to be eaten by scooping food with the bread, rather than using utensils, I ended up switching over to my fork pretty quickly.  Not because the scooping was difficult (it was actually quite fun), but because I wanted to save room for the food, rather than fill up on the bread. Since you eat with the bread, rather than utensils, it's easy to share.  I recommend going with a group, ordering a few different things, and sharing plates. Definitely pair your meal with the Ethiopian honey wine.  The sweetness of the wine is a beautiful complement to the spicy food.  It's sweet, but not overly sweet.  You can definitely taste the honey, but it's not overwhelming.During our meal, the owner came to check on us, which was a nice touch.  The only thing missing?  Dessert.  I'm not sure if it's served at Addis, but I was too full to even inquire!  I will definitely return to sample some more!

Top off the white pizza with your favorite Italian cheese and some shaved asparagus... it's to die for! The possibilities are really endless. Just be sure to follow the included instructions on how to treat the dough and you can not go wrong. I believe this is truly the best pizza in Richmond (with 8 1/2 coming in a close 2nd), and the fact that I can make it in my own oven is a delightful bonus.

<review# 951,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/11/2011,4/19/2012,13,67,,7,5>Pho So 1 used to be my go-to place for pho until I discovered Pho Tay Do. Since I get pho about once a week, I was definitely a regular. However, the trick to these small Vietnamese places is to figure out what they do well and to stick with it. At Pho So 1, they've consistently had the best grilled pork and broken rice dish (#31) out of all the places we've tried in Richmond. The pho here is okay, and it's more convenient than Pho Tay Do because it is larger and you can use debit/credit card to pay here. Although I prefer the way they cut some of their meat toppings to Tay Do, the broth here lacks the complexity of the pho broth at Tay Do, and sometimes it tastes like they are cutting corners by using beef broth powder or something like that to stretch the broth. Every once in a while I will still get the pho here, but I usually have to supplement the broth with sriracha, along with my usual toppings. The grilled pork here is mind-blowingly good, and the smell of it will hit you as you walk through the parking lot. The vermicelli bowl is scanty on veggies and herbs, relying too much on the pork (or other meat) and the noodles to fill you up. The bun bo hue here is awful. It barely tastes like the dish, so if you want to get bun bo hue, you're better off going to Vietnam Garden to get a decent version. The spring rolls here are so-so. You can get a much better version from Vi's Bakery on the road behind Pho So 1. The egg rolls (deep fried) are satisfying, but the version at Vietnam Garden is better. The iced coffee here is very good. Unlike Tay Do, it comes premixed over crushed ice, so you don't have control over how much condensed milk you want in it. It comes relatively sweet, which I like, but if you like more of a coffee taste, you might want to ask for less condensed milk. The salty lemonade (chanh muoi) here is better than all the other places I've tried it here in Richmond, and you have the option of getting it with club soda for some carbonation.Overall, I enjoy Pho So 1 for their grilled pork over broken rice, and I often stop in during the summer for a cup of their salty lemonade. When it comes to pho, however, you're better off at Pho Tay Do.

<review# 964,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/24/2014,8/27/2014,44,170,7,4,6>You're Ramen Me Crazy!  - Get it? Now.  We also tried the Gyoza, six lemongrass chicken dumplings in a "to die for" dipping sauce.  After trying the Bao Wow, I wanted to order more and more and more and more.  As for dinner, we opted for the Malaysian Ramen with a poached egg and also the Food Fried Rice.  The Malaysian Ramen was equally amazing as the Bao Wow and Gyoza.  I can't even explain it other than you must go now and order it.  The food fried rice was good but nothing to write home about.  I also ordered a to-go order of the Singapore Curried Noodles with chicken.  Good...but I think another ramen would have been a much, much better choice.Our service was great and the food was delicious.  Now that I know that the real focus here is their their "street food" and the ramen dishes, next time I'll skip anything else.  When you're ramen with me, you can't go wrong.  Get It? No? Ok, I'll just stop.Take care & savor it up!
<review# 965,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/9/2014,8/26/2014,62,150,3,9,5>Finally!  Good latin food in RVA.  Coming from FL, I missed restaurants where the menus are in Spanish and the food speaks for itself.  This place brought back a little home for me.  A place the serves me chicharron, fried pork belly and mini arepas to start a meal, will always have my attention.  Because I was so obsessed with the chicharron, I ordered the Frijoles Antioqueños which also came with beans, rice and avocado.  The beans were amazing and I cant wait to eat the leftovers tonight.   The hubs ordered the carne asada.  The meat was so flavorful, I kept eating off of his plate.  This may not be the fanciest place.  The seats are torn and its located in the Richmond Inn, but its clean and the service was amazing.  I may have found one of my favorite lunch spots!

<review# 967,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/15/2014,8/24/2014,4,9,3,4,4>Their ribs and macaroni and cheese are too much of a good thing. This is coming from someone who wouldn't normally choose ribs as a main course, or go out of my way to seek out ribs.  Normally too much of a good thing can be a bad thing, but definitely not with Buz and Ned's. Excellent original location on the Boulevard, but now since they've expanded to the West End, that's also another option. Awesome southern barbecue, you won't be let down with what they have available to order, make sure to try the okra and brisket always delivers. Buz and Ned's deserves to be featured on television and all the business they get from their publicity. Parking available on the side of the building, and the outdoor seating is great. If you can't find a spot on the side lot, look on Boulevard and see what is available.
<review# 968,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/3/2014,8/23/2014,10,49,1,13,7>Best of two worlds collide!  Turkish and Filipino food in one stop. It's easy to miss this family friendly restaurant if you're driving down Hull Street. Anyone seeing the restaurant from outside would have no idea what the small, inconspicuous  "Kamayan" sign means unless of course they're Filipino (like me!).  The scrumptious Baklava on display as I walked in was what clued me in that this was not just a Filipino restaurant.  Unfortunately, Turkish food would have to wait, I want me a taste of home! I ordered Sauteed Rice Noodles/Pancit, Chicken Curry, "Giniling"and "Halo-halo".Giniling is ground pork/beef stewed with potatoes and tomato sauce.  It will remind you of meat sauce for spaghetti but don't knock it until you try it over steamed rice!Chicken Curry is a popular Filipino comfort food and Kamayan's was flavorful.  A definite winner and a must try would be Kamayan's Pancit (pronounced as Pan-sit)  which is  made with Rice Noodles sauteed with pork/chicken and vegetables.  There are different varieties of Pancit/Filipino noodles depending if  rice or flour noodles are used in the dish.  Pancit is an international favorite for those familiar with Filipino cuisine, surprisingly not a favorite dish of mine but Kamayan Restaurant's Pancit/Noodles was awesome.Lastly, you won't see me walking out of a Filipino Restaurant without "Halo-halo" and this was as authentic as it can get.  Halo-halo is a shaved ice desert with various sweetened treats mixed in and topped off with milk, custard, and ice cream.  A must since Summer is Coming...
<review# 969,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/21/2014,8/22/2014,392,449,3,6,4>Chiocca's is located on a residential little street, basically in a basement. The chairs and tables are super close together, so you'll have to scoot past all of your neighbors just to get back to your booth.As previous reviews have stated, the service is very, very slow. I ordered a pastrami and swiss, and it came out about half an hour later, and it wasn't crowded at all. My sandwich came on rye and with some store bought chips. The sandwich itself was very, very solid. One of the better pastrami sandwiches I've ever had. So come on by and try one, but make sure you don't have anything scheduled for later. You'll be at Chiocca's for a while.
<review# 970,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/9/2014,8/21/2014,89,171,6,9,6>Living near the West End (and Richmond in general), there aren't too many open green places to visit and run around in.  Given that this weekend was amazingly nice out, despite it still being winter, we decided to check out Joseph Bryan Park.And it was glorious!  There are all sorts of fun things here from tennis courts, soccer fields (seriously, they have a whole soccer complex with like 6 full size fields), walking trails, biking trails, foresty areas, picnic areas, frisbee golf courses, fishing, an azalea garden, and more.  According to their website, there is a 260 acre area to explore and enjoy.We basically walked around the entire perimeter of the place and looked at all the park has to offer.  Being that it is still winter, the azalea gardens and landscaping wasn't in bloom (more or less still semi-dead and green-brown), but it's immediately apparent that it'd be a really beautiful place in the Spring.  Heck, even in the winter it was still pretty enough.The people visiting the place really breath life into it as well.  From children to dogs to families grilling out to groups of dudes playing frisbee golf, the place is really brought alive with people having a good time.  That said, there are also nice places to just sit down and relax or read a book.The reason I'm not giving it 5 stars, and maybe I'll update this come the spring and summer months, is that it's a little unclear exactly where you can and can't go.  Sure you physically can go anywhere, but we ended up walking down a path at the beginning that ended with us against a stream with no way to cross it (other than a sketchy 20 foot log or a super long jump).  Granted, we just turned around and continued our stroll and ultimately were just out to walk, but I know forced backtracking isn't normally an ideal feature.Oh, and certain parts of the park are pretty close to the highway or other driving / parking areas.  It's fenced in by the highway and admittedly that part is primarily hiking, so it's not really a danger to kids or dogs.We're definitely going to be returning here and can't wait to return in the spring and see the azalea gardens and the general greenness that should come along with it!  The addition of sporting things like tennis courts, soccer fields, and frisbee golf also make it a great place you could plan to visit with some friends too.  While it's not the greatest park I've ever been to and not as grand as Maymont for example, it is a great thing to have within a 15 minute drive and definitely worth checking out.
<review# 971,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/15/2014,8/20/2014,245,1116,,8,3>I have been a fan of Croakers Spot since they were Eggleston's.  Remember when?  I haven't been in a long while, though so I was glad to go last night.The Friday night dinner hour was hopping!  We put our names on the list and were told it'd be a 30-35 minute wait, and it was exactly 35 minutes.  I got the salmon cake dinner, which comes with cheddar ranch grits, fried cabbage and cornbread.  I also ordered a side of macaroni and cheese and a limeade to drink.  Considering how every table was taken and there was still a line at the door waiting to be seated, I was kind of surprised at how fast our food came out.  SO MUCH FOOD!The salmon cakes, cheddar ranch grits and fried cabbage were all good.  I don't remember the cornbread tasting the way it did last night.  It wasn't good.  It was dry and dense.  The macaroni and cheese wasn't great, either.  The mac was overcooked, and the cheese tasted processed.  The signature limeade was amazing.Service was fantastic.  The host was friendly.  Our server Serena/Selena was friendly, fast and accommodating.  Price was right, and you get SO MUCH FOOD for your dollar.  I took home half my meal.Atmosphere is great.  Diverse crowd.  Energetic.  LOUD... people are chatty and seem to have a good time.  Great background music -- 70s, 80s, 90s soul, R&B.  Beautiful space with exposed brick.  Colorful art.Definitely a hot spot.  Unfortunately, they don't do karaoke anymore :-(
